ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the different theories of IR and some practical implications to specific issue areas

Through the course I learned about 1) political theories on the roles of international law and organizations in global community and 2) research methods of political science to prove our hypotheses theoretically.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that overall the course was pretty solid. A point for improvement might be related to try to expand some of the issue topics such as the development which has several sub-ares in it.

Strength: The reading assignments helped me to understand the discussion among scholars not only about international organizations but also about broader topics of international relations, such as the theories of realism/liberalism/rationalism/constructivism and the functions of international law. The class discussion provided me with critical perspectives on preceding studies. Weakness: She sometimes didn't upload the reading assignments on Canvas.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interested in working in any of the issue areas of international development it is important to understand the theories and assumptions that underpin the ways in which IO work.
Yes I would. Even if a student is unfamiliar with theories of international relations, s/he can understand the points at issue through the course.
